The scene in which characters sing "Oh, Mr. Kane" was especially complicated and required mixing several soundtracks together.Rp104He also used different "sound perspectives" to create the illusion of distances,Rp101such as in scenes at Xanadu where characters speak to each other at far distances.Welles experimented with sound in post-production, creating audio montages,cite bookSchatzThomasHarpoleCharles (editor)History of the American Cinema, volume 6: Boom and bust, the American cinema in the 1940sUniversity of California PressBerkeley, Los Angeles, and London19970-520-22130-3Rp94and chose to create all of the sound effects for the film instead of using RKO's library of sound effects.Rp100

Welles used an aural technique from radio called the "lightning-mix". Welles used this technique to link complexfilm editingmontagesequences via a series of related sounds or phrases. For example, Kane grows from a child into a young man in just two shots. As Thatcher hands eight-year-old Kane a sled and wishes him a Merry Christmas, the sequence suddenly jumps to a shot of Thatcher fifteen years later, completing the sentence he began in both the previous shot and the chronological past. Other radio techniques include using a number of voices, each saying a sentence or sometimes merely a fragment of a sentence, and splicing the dialogue together in quick succession, such as the projection room scene.cite bookCookDavid A.A History of Narrative Film[[W. W. Norton & Company]]New York1982978-0-393-09022-2Rp413-412The film's sound cost $16,996, but was originally budgeted at $7,288.Rp105

Film critic and directorFranois Truffautwrote that "BeforeKane, nobody in Hollywood knew how to set music properly in movies.Kanewas the first, in fact the only, great film that uses radio techniques. A lot of filmmakers know enough to follow Auguste Renoir's advice to fill the eyes with images at all costs, but only Orson Welles understood that the sound track had to be filled in the same way."cite webhttp://thedancingimage.blogspot.com/2009/06/three-by-truffaut.htmlTruffautFranÃ§oisFranÃ§ois TruffautMayhewLeonard (translator)The Films in My Life''Simon and Schuster''New York19780-306-80599-5282Cedric BelfrageofThe Clipperwrote "of all of the delectable flavours that linger on the palate after seeingKane, the use of sound is the strongest."Rp1171
article.heading: Make-up
article.paragraph: The make-up forCitizen Kanewas created and applied by Maurice Seiderman (19071989), a junior member of the RKO make-up department.Rp19Seiderman's family came to the United States from Russia in 1920, escaping persecution.cite journalSmithDickDick Smith (make-up artist)OctoberâNovember 1999Citizen Seidermanhttp://mydigitalpublication.com/publication/?iMake-Up Artist Magazine2118â25January 25, 2015Rp18As a child Seiderman had won a drawing competition and received an apprenticeship at theMoscow Art Theatre,Rp157where his father was a wigmaker and make-up artist.cite journalGambillNormanNovemberâDecember 1978Making Up Kane[[Film Comment]]14642â48Rp42In New York his uncle was a theatrical scenic painter, and he helped Seiderman get into the union.Rp18He worked onMax Reinhardt's 1924 production ofThe Miracle (play)The Miracleand with the Yiddish Art Theatre,Rp157and he studied the human figure at theArt Students League of New York.Rp42After he moved to Los Angeles he was hired first byMax Factor, Sr.Max Factorand then by RKO.Rp19Seiderman had not been accepted into the union, which recognized him as only an apprentice, but RKO nevertheless used him to make up principal actors.Rp19

"Apprentices were not supposed to make up any principals, only extras, and an apprentice could not be on a set without a journeyman present," wrote make-up artistDick Smith (make-up artist)Dick Smith, who became friends with Seiderman in 1979. "During his years at RKO I suspect these rules were probably overlooked often."Rp19By 1940 Seiderman's uncredited film work includedWinterset (film)Winterset,Gunga Din (film)Gunga Din,The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1939 film)The Hunchback of Notre Dame,Swiss Family Robinson (1940 film)Swiss Family RobinsonandAbe Lincoln in Illinois (film)Abe Lincoln in Illinois.Rp48"Seiderman had gained a reputation as one of the most inventive and creatively precise up-and-coming makeup men in Hollywood," wrote biographer Frank Brady.Rp253

On an early tour of RKO, Welles met Seiderman in the small make-up lab he created for himself in an unused dressing room.Rp19"Welles fastened on to him at once," wrote biographer Charles Higham. "With his great knowledge of makeup indeed, his obsession with it, for he hated his flat nose Welles was fascinated Seiderman had an intimate knowledge of anatomy and the process of aging and was acquainted with every line, wrinkle and accretion of fat in aging men and women. Impatient with most makeup methods of his era, he used casts of his subjects in order to develop makeup methods that ensured complete naturalness of expression a naturalness unrivaled in Hollywood."Rp157

"WhenKanecame out in script form, Orson told all of us about the picture and said that the most important aspect was the makeup," Seiderman recalled. "I felt that I was being given an assignment that was unique so I worked accordingly. And there was a lot of work to do. Straight makeups were done in the makeup department by staff, but all the trick stuff and the principal characters were my personal work; nobody else ever touched them. They could not have handled it."Rp46

Seiderman developed a thorough plan for aging the principal characters, first making a plaster cast of the face of each of the actors who aged, except Joseph Cotten who was unavailable at that time. He made a plaster mold of Welles's body down to the hips.Rp46

"My sculptural techniques for the characters' aging were handled by adding pieces of white modeling clay, which matched the plaster, onto the surface of each bust," Seiderman told visual arts historian Norman Gambill. When Seiderman achieved the desired effect he cast the clay pieces in a soft plastic materialRp46that he formulated himself.Rp20These appliances were then placed onto the plaster bust and a four-piece mold was made for each phase of aging. The castings were then fully painted and paired with the appropriate wig for evaluation.Rp46â47

Before the actors went before the cameras each day, the pliable pieces were applied directly to their faces to recreate Seiderman's sculptural image. Welles was allergic to Max Factor's gum, so Seiderman invented an alternative that also photographed more realistically.Rp46The facial surface was underpainted in a flexible red plastic compound;Rp43Cotten recalled being instructed to puff out his cheeks during this process. Later, seeing the results in the mirror, Cotten told Seiderman, "I am acting the part of a nice old gentleman, not a relief map of the Rocky Mountains." Seiderman replied, "You'd be surprised at what the camera doesn't see unless we place it within its view. How about some more coffee?"cite bookCottenJosephJoseph CottenVanity Will Get You Somewhere[[Mercury House (publishers)|Mercury House]]San Francisco, CA1987978-0-916-51517-1Rp43

The red ground resulted in a warmth of tone that was picked up by the sensitivepanchromatic film. Over that was applied liquid greasepaint, and then finally a colorless translucent talcum.Rp42â43Seiderman created the effect of skin pores on Kane's face by stippling the surface with a negative cast he made from an orange peel.Rp42, 47

Welles was just as heavily made up as young Kane as he was for old Kane, and he often arrived on the set at 2:30 a.m.Rp69Application of the sculptural make-up for the oldest incarnation of the character took three-and-a-half hours. The make-up included appliances to age Welles's shoulders, breast and stomach.Rp19â20"In the film and production photographs, you can see that Kane had a belly that overhung," Seiderman said. "That was not a costume, it was the rubber sculpture that created the image. You could see how Kane's silk shirt clung wetly to the character's body. It could not have been done any other way."Rp46

Seiderman worked with Charles Wright on the wigs. These went over a flexible skull cover that Seiderman created and sewed into place with elastic thread. When he found the wigs too full he untied one hair at a time to alter their shape. Kane's mustache was inserted into the makeup surface a few hairs at a time, to realistically vary the color and texture.Rp43, 47

Seiderman madescleral lensesfor Welles, Dorothy Comingore, George Coulouris and Everett Sloane, to dull the brightness of their young eyes. The lenses took a long time to fit properly, and Seiderman began work on them before devising any of the other makeup. "I painted them to age in phases, ending with the blood vessels and theAurora Senilisof old age."Rp47efn<arg name="Seiderman's work with contact lenses in films led to a medical formula for soft [[contact lenses]] that he developed in the 1970s.{{cite news |title">Maurice Seiderman, 82, Inventor and Hollywood Makeup Artist |publisher

"Cotten was the only principal for whom I had not made any sculptural casts, wigs or lenses," Seiderman said. When Cotten's old-age scenes needed to be shot out of sequence due to Welles's injured ankle, Seiderman improvised with appliances made for Kane's make-up. A sun visor was chosen to conceal Cotten's low hairlineRp47â48and the lenses he wore hastily supplied by a Beverly Hills ophthalmologist were uncomfortable.Rp44â45

Seiderman's tour de force, the breakfast montage, was shot all in one day. "Twelve years, two years shot at each scene," he said. "Please realize, by the way, that a two-year jump in age is a bit harder to accomplish visually than one of twenty years."Rp47

As they did with art direction, the major studios gave screen credit for make-up to only the department head. When RKO make-up department headMel Bernsrefused to share credit with Seiderman, who was only an apprentice, Welles told Berns that there would be no make-up credit. Welles signed a large advertisement in the Los Angeles newspaper:Rp22Rp48

paragraph.extension:
THANKS TO EVERYBODY WHO GETS SCREEN CREDIT FOR "CITIZEN KANE"
AND THANKS TO THOSE WHO DON'T
TO ALL THE ACTORS, THE CREW, THE OFFICE, THE MUSICIANS, EVERYBODY
AND PARTICULARLY TO MAURICE SEIDERMAN, THE BEST MAKE-UP MAN IN THE WORLDRp20

article.paragraph: "To put this event in context, remember that I was a very low man," Seiderman recalled. "I wasn't even called a make-up man. I had started their laboratory and developed their plastic appliances for make-up. But my salary was $25 a week. And I had no union card."Rp48

Seiderman told Gambill that afterCitizen Kanewas released, Welles was invited to a White House dinner whereFrances Perkinswas among the guests. Welles told her about the Russian immigrant who did the make-up for his film but could not join the union. Seiderman said the head of the union received a call from the Labor Department the next day, and in November 1941 he was a full union member.Rp22Rp48efn<arg name="After becoming head of the RKO make-up department, Seiderman left in 1946 to help recreate faces for disfigured U.S. soldiers.{{cite news |last">Thomas |first
article.heading: Sets
article.paragraph: Although credited as an assistant, the film's art direction was done byPerry Ferguson.Rp85Welles and Ferguson got along during their collaboration.Rp37In the weeks before production began Welles, Toland and Ferguson met regularly to discuss the film and plan every shot, set design and prop. Ferguson would take notes during these discussions and create rough designs of the sets and story boards for individual shots. After Welles approved the rough sketches, Ferguson made miniature models for Welles and Toland to experiment on with aperiscopein order to rehearse and perfect each shot. Ferguson then had detailed drawings made for the set design, including the film's lighting design. The set design was an integral part of the film's overall look and Toland's cinematography.Rp42

In the original script the Great Hall at Xanadu was modeled after the Great Hall in Hearst Castle and its design included a mixture ofRenaissance architectureRenaissanceandGothic architectureGothicstyles.Rp50â51"The Hearstian element is brought out in the almost perverse juxtaposition of incongruous architectural styles and motifs," wrote Carringer.Rp54Before RKO cut the film's budget, Ferguson's designs were more elaborate and resembled the production designs of earlyCecil B. DeMillefilms andIntolerance (film)Intolerance.Rp55The budget cuts reduced Ferguson's budget by 33 percent and his work cost $58,775 total,Rp65which was below average at that time.Rp93To save costs Ferguson and Welles re-wrote scenes in Xanadu's living room and transported them to the Great Hall. A large staircase from another film was found and used at no additional cost.Rp56â57When asked about the limited budget, Ferguson said "Very often as in that much-discussed Xanadu set in Citizen Kane we can make a foreground piece, a background piece, and imaginative lighting suggest a great deal more on the screen than actually exists on the stage."Rp65â66According to the film's official budget there were 81 sets built, but Ferguson said there were between 106 and 116.Rp64

Still photographs ofOheka CastleinHuntington, New York, were used in the opening montage, representing Kane's Xanadu estate.cite webhttp://www.oheka.com/film-photo-shoots.htmOheka Castle â Film, Television and Photography ProductionsOheka.comMay 29, 2015cite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/1989/04/06/nyregion/c-corrections-910389.html?srcCorrections''The New York Times''April 6, 1989Ferguson also designed statue's from Kane's collection with styles ranging fromAncient Greek sculptureGreektoGothic artGerman Gothic.Rp61The sets were also built to accommodate Toland's camera movements. Walls were built to fold and furniture could quickly be moved. The film's famous ceilings were made out ofmuslinfabric and camera boxes were built into the floors for low angle shots.Rp64â65Welles later said that he was proud that the film production value looked much more expensive than the film's budget. Although neither worked with Welles again, Toland and Ferguson collaborated in several films in the 1940s.Rp65
article.heading: Special effects
article.paragraph: The film's special effects were supervised by RKO department headVernon L. Walker.Rp85Welles pioneered several visual effects to cheaply shoot things like crowd scenes and large interior spaces. For example, the scene in which the camera in the opera house rises dramatically to the rafters, to show the workmen showing a lack of appreciation for Susan Alexander Kane's performance, was shot by a cameraCrane shotcraningupwards over the performance scene, then awipe (transition)curtain wipeto a miniature of the upper regions of the house, and then another curtain wipe matching it again with the scene of the workmen. Other scenes effectively employed miniatures to make the film look much more expensive than it truly was, such as various shots of Xanadu.cite bookThomasFranÃ§oisNaremoreJames (Editor)Orson Welles's Citizen Kane: A CasebookOxford University PressOxford, UK and New York2004https://books.google.com/books?id978-0-19-515891-5November 10, 2007173

Some shots includedRear projection effectrear screen projectionin the background, such as Thompson's interview of Leland and some of the ocean backgrounds at Xanadu.Rp88Bordwell claims that the scene where Thatcher agrees to be Kane's guardian used rear screen projection to depict young Kane in the background, despite this scene being cited as a prime example of Toland's deep focus cinematography.Rp74A special effects camera crew from Walker's department was required for theClose-up#Types of close-upextreme close-upshots such as Kane's lips when he says "Rosebud" and the shot of the typewriter typing Susan's bad review.Rp88

Optical effects artist Dunn claimed that up to 80 percent of some reels was optically printed. These shots were traditionally attributed to Toland for years.cite bookJewellRichard B.The Golden Age of Cinema. Hollywood 1929-1945Blackwell PublishingOxford, UK2007978-1-405-16373-6Rp110The optical printer improved some of the deep focus shots.Rp92One problem with the optical printer was that it sometimes created excessivegraininess, such as the optical zoom out of the snow globe. Welles decided to superimpose snow falling to mask the graininess in these shots.Rp94Toland said that he disliked the results of the optical printer,Rp92but acknowledged that "RKO special effects expert Vernon Walker, ASC, and his staff handled their part of the production a by no means inconsiderable assignment with ability and fine understanding."Rp74â75

Any time deep focus was impossible  as in the scene in which Kane finishes a negative review of Susan's opera while at the same time firing the person who began writing the review  anoptical printerwas used to make the whole screen appear in focus, visually layering one piece of film onto another.Rp92However, some apparently deep-focus shots were the result ofin-camera effects, as in the famous scene in which Kane breaks into Susan's room after her suicide attempt. In the background, Kane and another man break into the room, while simultaneously the medicine bottle and a glass with a spoon in it are in closeup in the foreground. The shot was an in-cameraMatte (filmmaking)matteshot. The foreground was shot first, with the background dark. Then the background was lit, the foreground darkened, the film rewound, and the scene re-shot with the background action.Rp82
article.heading: Music
article.paragraph: The film's music was composed by Bernard Herrmann.cite bookSmithSteven C.A Heart at Fire's Center: The Life and Music of Bernard HerrmannUniversity of California PressOakland, California2002978-0-520-22939-6Rp72Herrmann had composed for Welles for his Mercury Theatre radio broadcasts.Rp63Because it was Herrmann's first motion picture score, RKO wanted to pay him only a small fee, but Welles insisted he be paid at the same rate asMax Steiner.Rp72

The score established Herrmann as an important new composer of film soundtrackscite webhttp://www.americancomposers.org/raksin_herrmann.htmAmerican Composers Orchestra â David Raksin remembers his colleaguesAmericancomposers.orgJanuary 22, 2009and eschewed the typical Hollywood practice of scoring a film with virtually non-stop music. Instead Herrmann used what he later described as '"radio scoring", musical cues typically 515 seconds in length that bridge the action or suggest a different emotional response.Rp77â78The breakfast montage sequence begins with a graceful waltz theme and gets darker with each variation on that theme as the passage of time leads to the hardening of Kane's personality and the breakdown of his first marriage.cite webhttp://www.americanmusicpreservation.com/CitizenKanefilmscore.htm70th anniversary of Citizen Kane and Bernard Herrmann's film scoreApril 27, 2011cite webhttp://www.filmsite.org/citi4.htmlDirksTimCitizen Kane, page 4filmsite.orgNovember 29, 2014

Herrmann realized that musicians slated to play his music were hired for individual unique sessions; there was no need to write for existing ensembles. This meant that he was free to score for unusual combinations of instruments, even instruments that are not commonly heard. In the opening sequence, for example, the tour of Kane's estate Xanadu, Herrmann introduces a recurringleitmotivplayed by low woodwinds, including a quartet ofalto flutes.cite webhttp://www.filmscorerundowns.net/herrmann/citizenkane.pdfWrobelBillHerrmann's "Citizen Kane"PDFNovember 4, 2001July 31, 20132

For Susan Alexander Kane's operatic sequence, Welles suggested that Herrmann compose a witty parody of aMary Gardenvehicle, an aria fromSalammb.Rp57"Our problem was to create something that would give the audience the feeling of the quicksand into which this simple little girl, having a charming but small voice, is suddenly thrown," Herrmann said.Rp79Writing in the style of a 19th-century French Oriental opera,Herrmann put the aria in a key that would force the singer to strain to reach the high notes, culminating in a high D, well outside the range of Susan Alexander.Rp79â80Soprano Jean Forward dubbed the vocal part for Comingore.Houseman claimed to have written the libretto, based onJean RacinesAthalieandPhedre,Rp460â461although some confusion remains sinceLucille Fletcherremembered preparing the lyrics.Rp80Fletcher, then Herrmann's wife, wrote the libretto for his operaWuthering Heights (Herrmann)Wuthering Heights.Rp11

Music enthusiasts consider the scene in which Susan Alexander Kane attempts to sing the famous cavatina "Una voce poco fa" fromIl barbiere di SivigliabyGioachino Rossiniwith vocal coach Signor Matiste as especially memorable for depicting the horrors of learning music through mistakes.cite webhttp://www.concertonet.com/scripts/review.php?ID_reviewKirshnitFrederick L.Champagne and PomadeConcertoNet.comParis, FranceDecember 31, 2004December 11, 2014

In 1972 Herrmann said, "I was fortunate to start my career with a film likeCitizen Kane, it's been a downhill run ever since!" Welles loved Herrmann's score and told directorHenry Jaglomthat it was 50 percent responsible for the film's artistic success.Rp84

Some incidental music came from other sources. Welles heard the tune used for the publisher's theme, "Oh, Mr. Kane", in Mexico.Rp57Called "A Poco No", the song was written byPepe Guzarand special lyrics were written by Herman Ruby.cite webhttp://folk.uib.no/smkgg/midi/soundtrackweb/herrmann/db/cuesheets/film_citizenkane.htmlCue Sheet: Citizen KaneApril 22, 1941The Bernard Herrmann SocietyDecember 26, 2014

"In a Mizz", a 1939 jazz song byCharlie Barnetand Haven Johnson, bookends Thompson's second interview of Susan Alexander Kane.Rp108"I kind of based the whole scene around that song," Welles said. "The music is byNat King ColeNat Coleit's his trio."Rp56Later beginning with the lyrics, "It can't be love" "In a Mizz" is performed at the Everglades picnic, framing the fight in the tent between Susan and Kane.Rp108Musicians including bandleaderCee Pee Johnson(drums), Alton Redd (vocals), Raymond Tate (trumpet),Buddy Collette(alto sax) andBuddy Banks (saxophonist)Buddy Banks(tenor sax) are featured.cite webhttp://lcweb2.loc.gov/diglib/ihas/loc.natlib.jots.200014490/default.htmlJazz on the Screen: A jazz and blues filmography by David Meeker[[Library of Congress]]February 21, 2014

All of the music used in the newsreel came from the RKO music library, edited at Welles's request by the newsreel department to achieve what Herrmann called "their own crazy way of cutting". TheNews on the Marchtheme that accompanies the newsreel titles is "Belgian March" byAnthony Vincent CollinsAnthony Collins, from the filmNurse Edith Cavell. Other examples are an excerpt fromAlfred Newman (composer)Alfred Newman's score forGunga Din (film)Gunga Din(the exploration of Xanadu),Roy Webb's theme for the filmReno (1939 film)Reno(the growth of Kane's empire), and bits of Webb's score forFive Came Back(introducing Walter Parks Thatcher).Rp79
article.heading: Editing
article.paragraph: One of the editing techniques used inCitizen Kanewas the use of montage to collapse time and space, using an episodic sequence on the same set while the characters changed costume and make-up between cuts so that the scene following each cut would look as if it took place in the same location, but at a time long after the previous cut. In the breakfast montage, Welles chronicles the breakdown of Kane's first marriage in five vignettes that condense 16 years of story time into two minutes of screen time.cite bookCostanzo CahirLindaLiterature into film: theory and practical approaches[[McFarland & Company]]Jefferson, North Carolina2006978-0-7864-2597-659â60Welles said that the idea for the breakfast scene "... was stolen fromThe Long Christmas DinnerofThornton Wilder... a one-act play, which is a long Christmas dinner that takes you through something like 60 years of a family's life."Rp51June 2012The film often used long dissolves to signify the passage of time and its psychological effect of the characters, such as the scene where the abandoned sled gets covered with snow after the young Kane is sent away with Thatcher.Rp90â91

Welles was influenced by the editing theories ofSergei Eisensteinby using jarring cuts that caused "sudden graphic or associative contrasts", such as the cut from Kane's deathbed to the beginning of the "News on the March" sequence and a sudden shot of a shrieking bird at the beginning of Raymond's flashback.Rp88â89Although the film typically favors mise-en-scne over montage, the scene where Kane goes to Susan Alexander's apartment after first meeting her is the only one that is primarily cut as close-ups with shots and counter shots between Kane and Susan.Rp68Fabe says that "by using a standard Hollywood technique sparingly, [Welles] revitalizes its psychological expressiveness."Rp88
article.heading: Themes
Political themes
article.paragraph: In her 1992 monograph for theBritish Film Institute, critic Laura Mulvey explored the anti-fascist themes ofCitizen Kane. TheNews on the Marchnewsreel presents Kane keeping company with Hitler and other dictators while he smugly assures the public there will be no war.cite bookMcBrideJoseph2006What Ever Happened to Orson Welles? A Portrait of an Independent CareerLexington, Kentucky[[University Press of Kentucky]]0-8131-2410-7Rp44Mulvey wrote that the film reflects "the battle between intervention and isolationism" then being waged in the United States; the film was released six months before the attack on Pearl Harbor, while PresidentFranklin D. Rooseveltwas laboring to win public opinion for entering World War II. "Not only was the war in Europe the burning public issue of the time," Mulvey wrote, "it was of passionate personal importance to Orson Welles In the rhetoric ofCitizen Kane, the destiny of isolationism is realised in metaphor: in Kane's own fate, dying wealthy and lonely, surrounded by the detritus of European culture and history."Rp15

JournalistIgnacio Ramonethas cited the film as an early example ofmass mediaCrowd manipulationmanipulationofpublic opinionand the power thatmedia conglomerateshave on influencing the democratic process. Ramonet believes that this early example of a media mogul influencing politics is outdated and that "today Citizen Kane would be a dwarf. He owned a few papers in one country. The forces that dominate today have integrated image with text and sound and the world is their market. There are media groups with the power of a thousand Citizen Kanes."cite newsRamonetIgnacioIgnacio RamonetSet the media free''[[Le Monde diplomatique]]''Paris, Francehttp://mondediplo.com/2003/10/01mediaOctober 2003December 7, 2014cite newsDedijerMikiThe man behind Attac''Dedijer Media AB''Stockholm, Swedenhttp://dedijer.com/article_frames.asp?picts2000December 9, 2014Media mogulRupert Murdochis sometimes labeled as a latter-dayCitizen Kane.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/2162658.stmWalkerAndrewRupert Murdoch: Bigger than Kane''[[BBC News]]''July 31, 2002cite bookTuccilleJeromeJerome TuccilleRupert Murdoch: Creator of a Worldwide Media EmpireBeard BooksWashington D.C.1989https://books.google.com/books?id978-1-587-9822-48xiv
article.heading: Reception
Pre-release controversy
article.paragraph: To ensure thatCitizen Kane's influence from Hearst's life was a secret, Welles limited access todailiesand managed the film's publicity.Rp111April 2012Publicity materials in the December 1940 issue ofStagestated the film's inspiration wasFaust,cite newsNewmanKimKim NewmanFreerIanIan FreerFraserRobCitizen Kane''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]''July 2003146â156but made no mention of Hearst.Rp111

The film was scheduled to premiere at RKO's flagship theater Radio City Music Hall on February 14, but in early January 1941 Welles was not finished with post-production work and told RKO that it still needed its musical score.Rp205December 2014Writers for national magazines had early deadlines and so a rough cut was previewed for a select few on January 3, 1941Rp111April 2012for such magazines asLife,LookandRedbook. Gossip columnistHedda Hopper(and Parsons' arch rival) showed up to the screening uninvited. Most of the critics at the preview said that they liked the film and gave it good advanced reviews. Hopper wrote negatively about it, calling the film a viscous and irresponsible attack on a great man and criticizing its corny writing and old fashioned photography.Rp205December 2014Fridaymagazine ran an article drawing point-by-point comparisons between Kane and Hearst and documented how Welles had led on Parsons, Hollywood correspondent for Hearst papers.Rp111April 2012Up until this Welles had been friendly with Parsons. The magazine quoted Welles as saying that he couldnt understand why she was so nice to him and that she should wait until the woman finds out that the pictures about her boss. Welles immediately denied making the statement and the editor ofFridayadmitted that it may be false. Welles apologized to Parsons and assured her that he had never made that remark.Rp205December 2014

link.part: Film columnist and Hearst employeeLouella Parsonswas humiliated by ''Citizen Kane'' and began making numerous threats to prevent the film from being released.

article.paragraph: Shortly afterFriday's article Hearst sent Parsons an angry letter complaining that he had learned aboutCitizen Kanefrom Hopper and not her. The incident made a fool of Parsons and compelled her to start attacking Welles and the film. Parsons demanded a private screening of the film and personally threatened Schaffer on Hearsts behalf, first with a lawsuit and then with a vague threat of consequences for everyone in Hollywood. On January 10 Parsons and two lawyers working for Hearst were given a private screening of the film.Rp206December 2014James G. Stewart was present at the screening and said that she walked out of the film.Rp11Soon after, Parsons called Schaefer and threatened RKO with a lawsuit if they releasedKane.Rp111April 2012She also contacted the management of Radio City Music Hall and demanded that they not screen it.Rp206December 2014The next day, the front page headline inDaily Varietyread, "HEARST BANS RKO FROM PAPERS."cite newsHearst Bans RKO From Papers''[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]]''January 10, 1941Hearst began this ban by suppressing promotion of RKO'sKitty Foyle (film)Kitty Foyle,Rp94but in two weeks the ban was lifted for everything exceptKane.Rp111April 2012

When Schaefer did not submit to Parsons she called other studio heads and made more threats on behalf of Hearst to expose the private lives of people throughout the entire film industry.Rp206December 2014Welles was threatened with an expos about his romance with the married actressDelores del Rio, who wanted the affair kept secret until her divorce was finalized.Rp207December 2014In a statement to journalists Welles denied that the film was about Hearst. Hearst began preparing an injunction against film for libel and invasion of privacy, but Welless lawyer told him that he doubted Hearst would proceed due to the negative publicity and requited testimony that an injunction would bring.Rp209December 2014

The Hollywood Reporterran a front-page story on January 13 that Hearst papers were about to run a series of editorials attacking Hollywood's practice of hiring refugees and immigrants for jobs that could be done by Americans. The goal was to put pressure on the other studios to force RKO to shelveKane.Rp111April 2012Many of those immigrants had fled Europe after the rise of fascism and feared losing the safe haven of the United States.Rp209December 2014Soon afterwards, Schaefer was approached byNicholas Schenck, head ofMetro-Goldwyn-Mayer's parent company, with an offer on the behalf ofLouis B. Mayerand other Hollywood executives made an offer to RKO Pictures of $805,000 to destroy all prints of the film and burn the negative.Rp111â112April 2012cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/the-greatest-story-ever-told-sixty-years-of-citizen-kane-682857.htmlThomsonDavidThe greatest story ever told: Sixty years of Citizen Kane''[[The Independent]]''LondonApril 28, 2001December 26, 2009Once RKO's legal team reassured Schaefer, the studio announced on January 21 thatKanewould be released as scheduled, and with one of the largest promotional campaigns in the studio's history. Schaefer brought Welles to New York City for a private screening of the film with the New York corporate heads of the studios and their lawyers.Rp112April 2012There was no objection to its release provided that certain changes, including the removal or softening of specific references that might offend Hearst, were made.Rp112â113April 2012Welles agreed and cut the running time from 122 minutes to 119 minutes. The cuts satisfied the corporate lawyers.Rp113April 2012
article.heading: Hearst's response
article.paragraph: Hearing aboutCitizen Kaneenraged Hearst so much that he banned any advertising, reviewing, or mentioning of it in his papers, and had his journalistslibelWelles.Welles used Hearst's opposition as a pretext for previewing the film in several opinion-making screenings in Los Angeles, lobbying for its artistic worth against the hostile campaign that Hearst was waging.A special press screening took place in early March. Henry Luce was in attendance and reportedly wanted to buy the film from RKO for $1 million to distribute it himself. The reviews for this screening were positive. AHollywood Reviewheadline read, "Mr. Genius Comes Through; 'Kane' Astonishing Picture". TheMotion Picture Heraldreported about the screening and Welles's intention to sue RKO.Timemagazine wrote that "The objection of Mr. Hearst, who founded a publishing empire on sensationalism, is ironic. For to most of the several hundred people who have seen the film at private screenings,Citizen Kaneis the most sensational product of the U.S. movie industry." A second press screening occurred in April.Rp94

When Schaefer rejected Hearst's offer to suppress the film, Hearst banned every newspaper and station in his mediaConglomerate (company)conglomeratefrom reviewing  or even mentioning  the film. He also had many movie theaters ban it, and many did not show it through fear of being socially exposed by his massive newspaper empire.cite newsStreetSarahCitizen Kane''History Today''March 1996The Oscar-nominated documentaryThe Battle Over Citizen Kanelays the blame for the film's relative failure squarely at the feet of Hearst. The film did decent business at the box office; it went on to be the sixth highest grossing film in its year of release, a modest success its backers found acceptable. Nevertheless, the film's commercial performance fell short of its creators' expectations.Hearst's biographer David Nasaw points out that Hearst's actions were not the only reasonKanefailed, however: the innovations Welles made with narrative, as well as the dark message at the heart of the film (that the pursuit of success is ultimately futile) meant that a popular audience could not appreciate its merits.cite bookNasawDavidDavid NasawThe Chief: The Life of William Randolph Hearst[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]Boston,MA20000-395-82759-0Rp572â573April 2012

Hearst's attacks against Welles went beyond attempting to suppress the film. Welles said that while he was on his post-filming lecture tour a police detective approached him at a restaurant and advised him not to go back to his hotel. A 14-year-old girl had reportedly been hidden in the closet of his room, and two photographers were waiting for him to walk in. Knowing he would be jailed after the resulting publicity, Welles did not return to the hotel but waited until the train left town the following morning. "But that wasn't Hearst," Welles said, "that was a hatchet man from the local Hearst paper who thought he would advance himself by doing it."Rp85â86

In March 1941 Welles directed a Broadway version ofRichard Wright (author)Richard Wright'sNative Son(and, for luck, used a "Rosebud" sled as a prop).Native Son (play)Native Sonreceived positive reviews, but Hearst-owned papers used the opportunity to attack Welles as a communist.Rp213December 2014The Hearst papers vociferously attacked Welles after his April 1941 radio play, "His Honor, the Mayor", produced for The Free Company radio series on CBS.cite bookWoodBretBret WoodOrson Welles: A Bio-BibliographyGreenwood PressWestport, Connecticut19900-313-26538-0Rp113cite webhttp://www.wellesnet.com/?pOrson Welles defends American civil liberties in His Honor the MayorWellesnet.comAugust 4, 2007December 26, 2014

Welles described his chance encounter with Hearst in an elevator at theFairmont San FranciscoFairmont Hotelon the nightCitizen Kaneopened in San Francisco. Hearst and Welles's father were acquaintances, so Welles introduced himself and asked Hearst if he would like to come to the opening. Hearst did not respond. "As he was getting off at his floor, I said, 'Charles Foster Kane would have accepted.' No reply", recalled Welles. "And Kane would have you know. That was his style just as he finished Jed Leland's bad review of Susan as an opera singer."Rp49â50

In 1945 Hearst journalist Robert Shaw wrote that the film got "a full tide of insensate fury" from Hearst papers, "then it ebbed suddenly. With one brain cell working, the chief realized that such hysterical barking by the trained seals would attract too much attention to the picture. But to this day the name of Orson Welles is on the official son-of-a-bitch list of every Hearst newspaper."Rp102

Despite Hearst's attempts to destroy the film, since 1941 references to his life and career have usually included a reference toCitizen Kane, such as the headline 'Son of Citizen Kane Dies' for the obituary of Hearst's son.cite newsKingSusanRaising 'Kane' With Hearst : An 'American Experience' Recounts the Attempts of the Publishing Magnate to Quash a Film Masterpiece''Los Angeles Times''Los Angeles, CAhttp://articles.latimes.com/1996-01-28/news/tv-29475_1_citizen-kaneJanuary 28, 1996December 11, 2014In 2012 the Hearst estate agreed to screen the film at Hearst Castle in San Simeon, breaking Hearst's ban on the film.cite newsChawkinsSteveFamily 'Citizen Kane' gets inside the castle''Los Angeles Times''Los Angeles, CAhttp://articles.latimes.com/2012/jan/23/local/la-me-citizen-kane-20120123January 23, 2012December 11, 2014
article.heading: Release
article.paragraph: Radio City Music Hall's management refused to screenCitizen Kanefor its premiere. A possible factor was Parsons's threat thatThe American Weeklywould run a defamatory story on the grandfather of major RKO stockholder Nelson Rockefeller.Rp115April 2012Other exhibitors feared being sued for libel by Hearst and refused to show the film.Rp216December 2014In March Welles threatened the RKO board of governors with a lawsuit if they did not release the film. Schaefer stood by Welles and opposed the board of governors.Rp210December 2014When RKO still delayed the film's release Welles offered to buy the film for $1 million and the studio finally agreed to release the film on May 1.Rp215December 2014

Schaefer managed to book a few theaters willing to show the film. Hearst papers refused to accept advertising in its papers.Rp115April 2012RKO's publicity advertisements for the film erroneously promoted it as a love story.Rp217December 2014

Kaneopened at thePalace Theatre (New York City)RKO Palace TheatreonBroadway (Manhattan)Broadwayin New York on May 1, 1941,in Chicago on May 6, and in Los Angeles on May 8.Rp115April 2012Welles said that at the Chicago premiere that he attended the theater was almost empty.Rp216December 2014It did well in cities and larger towns but fared poorly in more remote areas. RKO still had problems getting exhibitors to show the film. For example, one chain controlling more than 500 theaters got Welles's film as part of a package but refused to play it, reportedly out of fear of Hearst.Rp117April 2012Hearst's disruption of the film's release damaged its box office performance and, as a result, it lost $160,000 during its initial run.cite bookJewellRichard B.HarbinVernonThe RKO Story[[Arlington House Publishers]]/[[Crown Publishing Group]]New York1982978-0-517-54656-7Rp164April 2012cite newsJewellRichardRKO Film Grosses: 1931â1951''Historical Journal of Film Radio and Television'', Vol 14 No 1199445The film earned $23,878 during its first week in New York. By the ninth week it only made $7,279. Overall it lost money in New York, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington, D.C., but made a profit in Seattle.Rp216December 2014
article.heading: Contemporary responses
article.paragraph: Citizen Kanereceived good reviews from several critics.New York Daily Newscritic Kate Cameron called it "one of the most interesting and technically superior films that has ever come out of a Hollywood studio".cite newsCameronKateCitizen Kane''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily-News]]''May 2, 1941New York World-Telegramcritic William Boehnel said that the film was "staggering and belongs at once among the greatest screen achievements".cite newsBoehnelWilliamCitizen Kane''[[New York World-Telegram]]''May 2, 1941Timemagazine wrote that "it has found important new techniques in picture-making and story-telling."Rp211December 2014Lifemagazine's review said that "few movies have ever come from Hollywood with such powerful narrative, such original technique, such exciting photography."Rp211December 2014John C. Mosher ofThe New Yorkercalled the film's style "like fresh air" and raved "Something new has come to the movie world at last."Rp68Anthony Bower ofThe Nationcalled it "brilliant" and praised the cinematography and performances by Welles, Comingore and Cotten.cite newsBowerAnthonyCitizen Kane[[The Nation]]New YorkApril 26, 1941John O'Hara'sNewsweekreview called it the best picture he'd ever seen and said Welles was "the best actor in the history of acting."Rp211December 2014Welles called O'Hara's review "the greatest review that anybody ever had."Rp100
The day following the premiere ofCitizen Kane,The New York TimescriticBosley Crowtherwrote that "... it comes close to being the most sensational film ever made in Hollywood."

paragraph.extension: Count on Mr. Welles: he doesn't do things by halves. ... Upon the screen he discovered an area large enough for his expansive whims to have free play. And the consequence is that he has made a picture of tremendous and overpowering scope, not in physical extent so much as in its rapid and graphic rotation of thoughts. Mr. Welles has put upon the screen a motion picture that really moves.cite newsCrowtherBosleyBosley CrowtherOrson Welles's Controversial 'Citizen Kane' Proves a Sensational Film at Palace''The New York Times''May 2, 1941

article.paragraph: In the UKC. A. LejeuneofThe Observercalled it "The most exciting film that has come out of Hollywood in twenty-five years"cite newsLejeuneC. A.C. A. LejeuneThe most exciting film that has come out of Hollywood in twenty-five years''[[The Observer]]''London, UKhttp://www.theguardian.com/film/1941/oct/12/derekmalcolmscenturyoffilmOctober 12, 1941December 11, 2014andDilys PowellofThe Sunday Timessaid the film's style was made "with the ease and boldness and resource of one who controls and is not controlled by his medium."Rp63December 2014Edward Tangye LeanofHorizon (magazine)Horizonpraised the films technical style, calling it "perhaps a decade ahead of its contemporaries."cite newsLeanTangyeEdward Tangye LeanPre-War Citizen''[[Horizon (magazine)|Horizon]]''London, UKNovember 1941efn<arg name="Kevin Brownlow believes that Lean's brother [[David Lean|David]] was influential on (if not co-writer of) this review. Years later Welles thanked David Lean for the article.{{cite book|last">Brownlow |first

A few reviews were mixed.Otis FergusonofThe New Republicsaid it was "the boldest free-hand stroke in major screen production sinceD.W. GriffithGriffithandBilly BitzerBitzerwere running wild to unshackle the camera", but also criticized its style, calling it a "retrogression in film technique" and stating that "it holds no great place" in film history.cite newsFergusonOtisOtis FergusonCitizen Kane''[[The New Republic]]''June 2, 1941In a rare film review, filmmakerErich von Stroheimcriticized the film's story and non-linear structure, but praised the technical style and performances, and wrote "Whatever the truth may be about it, "Citizen Kane" is a great picture and will go down in screen history. More power to Welles!"cite newsvon StroheimErichErich von StroheimCitizen Kane''Decision, a review of free culture'', Volume 1, number 6http://www.fredcamper.com/M/VonStroheim.htmlJune 6, 1941December 16, 201491â93

Some prominent critics wrote negative reviews. article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: Citizen Kanemarked a decline in Welles's success. Author Joseph McBride said the problems in making the film caused damage to his career. This started in 1942 when RKO violated its contract with Welles by re-editingThe Magnificent Ambersons (film)The Magnificent Ambersonsagainst his will.That June, Schaefer resigned from RKO and Welles's contract was promptly terminated.

Welles himself has been retroactively compared to Charles Foster Kane. Wise believed that Kane resembled Welles's life story more than Hearst's and said "Orson was doing an autobiographical film and didn't realize it, because it's rather much the same, you know. You start here, and you have a big rise and tremendous prominence and fame and success and whatnot, and then tail off and tail off and tail off. And at least the arc of the two lives were very much the same."Bogdanovich disagreed with this and said that Kane "had none of the qualities of an artist, Orson had all the qualities of an artist." Bogdanovich also noted that Welles was never bitter "about all the bad things that happened to him" and enjoyed life in his final years.cite videoWellesOrsonCitizen Kane, ''Peter Bogdanovich audio commentary''DVDWarner Home Video2001

The 1999HBOTelevision filmfilmRKO 281depicted the making of the film and Hearst's attempts to prevent its release. It was based on the documentaryThe Battle over Citizen Kane, but differed from its source by "downplaying [Mankiewicz's] role in bringing the idea of a Hearst-based movie"cite newsFriesLauraReview: âRKO 281â''Variety''http://variety.com/1999/tv/reviews/rko-281-1200459734/November 14, 1999December 10, 2014and inventing such historically inaccurate incidents as Welles visiting Hearst Castle and meeting Hearst before writing the film's script.cite webhttp://www.nitrateonline.com/1999/rrko281.htmlAxmakerSeanRKO 281Nitrate Productions, Inc.November 19, 1999December 11, 2014

The film is in the past tense, whereas we all know that cinema has got to be in the present tense."cite newsSartreJean-PaulJean-Paul SartreQuand Hollywood veut faire penser: âCitizen Kaneâ film dâOrson Welles''LâEcran francais'', number 5Paris, FranceAugust 1, 1945cite newshttp://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2014/08/12/sartre-and-borges-on-welles/PiepenbringDanSartre and Borges on Welles''[[The Paris Review]]''Paris, FranceAugust 12, 2014December 11, 2014

link.part: Film theoristAndr Bazin(author of ''Qu'est-ce que le cinma?'') based many of his theories around the film and has been called the most influential person to enhance its reputation.

article.paragraph: Andr Bazin, a little known film critic working for Sartre'sLes Temps modernes, was asked to give anImpromptu speakingimpromptu speechabout the film after a screening at the Colise Theatre in the autumn of 1946Rp36and changed the opinion of much of the audience. This speech led to Bazin's 1947 article "The Technique of Citizen Kane",Rp125which directly influenced public opinion about the film.Rp124Carringer wrote that Bazin was "the one who did the most to enhance the films reputation."Rp118efn<arg name="Bordwell has hypothesized that Bazin was influenced by publicity about the film's innovations that were published in France during its first release. These included interviews by Welles and the publication of Toland's article "The Motion Picture Cameraman" in the January 1947 issue of ''La Revue du CinÃ©ma''. Bordwell believes that Bazin was aware of the legend of filmâs innovations before having seen it.<ref name">"Minding"/>{{Rp|72â73}}Both Bazin's critique of the film and his theories about cinema itself centered around his strong belief inmise en scne. These theories were diametrically opposed to both the popularSoviet montage theoryRpxiiiand the politicallyMarxistand anti-Hollywood beliefs of most French film critics at that time.Rp36Bazin believed that a film should depict reality without the filmmaker imposing their "will" on the spectator, which the Soviet theory supported.RpxiiiBazin wrote thatCitizen Kane's mise en scne created a "new conception of filmmaking"Rp233and that the freedom given to the audience from the deep focus shots was innovative by changing the entire concept of the cinematic image.Rp128Bazin wrote extensively about the mise en scne in the scene where Susan Alexander attempts suicide, which was one long take while other films would have used four or five shots in the scene.Rp234Bazin wrote that the film's mise en scne "forces the spectator to participate in the meaning of the film" and creates "a psychological realism which brings the spectator back to the real conditions of perception."Rp72

In his 1950 essay "The Evolution of the Language of Cinema", Bazin placedCitizen Kanecenter stage as a work which ushered in a new period in cinema.cite bookBazinAndrÃ©What is Cinema?University of California PressOakland, CA1950978-0-520-24227-2Rp37One of the first critics to defend motion pictures as being on the same artistic level as literature or painting, Bazin often used the film as an example of cinema as an art formRp129and wrote that "Welles has given the cinema a theoretical restoration. He has enriched his filmic repertory with new or forgotten effects that, in todays artistic context, take on a significance we didnt know they could have."Rp236Bazin also compared the film toRoberto Rossellini'sPaisfor having "the same aesthetic concept of realism"Rp117â118and to the films ofWilliam Wylershot by Toland (such asThe Little Foxes (film)The Little FoxesandThe Best Years of Our Lives), all of which used deep focus cinematography that Bazin called "a dialectical step forward in film language."Rp71

Bazin's praise of the film went beyond film theory and reflected his own philosophy towards life itself.Rp125His metaphysical interpretations about the film reflected human kinds place in the universe.Rp128Bazin believed that the film examined one persons identity and search for meaning. It portrayed the world as ambiguous and full of contradictions, whereas films up until then simply portrayed peoples actions and motivations.Rp130Bazin's biographerDudley Andrewwrote that:

paragraph.extension: The world ofCitizen Kane, that mysterious, dark, and infinitely deep world of space and memory where voices trail off into distant echoes and where meaning dissolves into interpretation, seemed to Bazin to mark the starting point from which all of us try to construct provisionally the sense of our lives.Rp129

article.paragraph: Bazin went on to co-foundCahiers du cinma, whose contributors (including future film directors Franois Truffaut andJean-Luc Godard) also praised the film.Rp37The popularity of Truffaut'sauteur theoryhelped the film's and Welles's reputation.cite bookBordwellDavidDavid BordwellThompsonKristinKristin ThompsonFilm History: An IntroductionMcGraw-Hill inc.New York1994978-0-073-38613-3Rp263
article.heading: Re-evaluation
article.paragraph: By 1942Citizen Kanehad run its course theatrically and, apart from a few showings at big city arthouse cinemas, it largely vanished and both the film's and Welles's reputation fell among American critics. In 1949 critic Richard Griffith in his overview of cinema,The Film Till Now, dismissedCitizen Kaneas "... tinpot if not crackpotSigmund FreudFreud."Rp117â118April 2012

Citizen Kanewas re-released in 1952 after gaining popularity on TV. A journalist from theThe Evening News (London newspaper)London Evening Newswrote that after seeing the film for the first time he came away marveling.Rp49

In the United States, it was neglected and forgotten until its revival on television in the mid-1950s. Three key events in 1956 led to its re-evaluation in the United States: first, RKO was one of the first studios to sell its library to television, and early that yearCitizen Kanestarted to appear on television; second, the film was re-released theatrically to coincide with Welles's return to the New York stage, where he playedKing Lear; and third, American film critic Andrew Sarris wrote "Citizen Kane: The American Baroque" forFilm Culture, and described it as "the great American film" and "the work that influenced the cinema more profoundly than any American film sinceBirth of a Nation."cite newsSarrisAndrewAndrew SarrisCitizen Kane: The American Baroque''[[Film Culture]]'', number 91956Carringer considers Sarris's essay as the most important influence on the film's reputation in the US.Rp119

DuringExpo 58, a poll of over 100 film historians namedKaneone of the top ten greatest films ever made (the group gave first-place honors toThe Battleship Potemkin). When a group of young film directors announced their vote for the top six, they were booed for not including the film.

In the decades since, its critical status asfilms that have been considered the greatest everthe greatest film ever madehas grown, with numerous essays and books on it including Peter Cowie'sThe Cinema of Orson Welles, Ronald Gottesman'sFocus on Citizen Kane, a collection of significant reviews and background pieces, and most notably Kael's essay, "Raising Kane", which promoted the value of the film to a much wider audience than it had reached before.Rp120April 2012Despite its criticism of Welles, it further popularized the notion ofCitizen Kaneas the great American film. The rise of art house and film society circuits also aided in the film's rediscovery.Rp119April 2012David Thomson said that the film 'grows with every year as America comes to resemble it."Rp1172

article.heading: Film memorabilia
article.paragraph: In 1982, film director Steven Spielberg bought a "Rosebud" sled for $60,500; it was one of threebalsasleds used in the closing scenes and the only one that was not burned.cite newsNewsmakers''[[Newsweek]]''June 21, 198251cite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/opinion/topics-hidden-treasures-prop-art.htmlHidden Treasures: Prop Art''The New York Times''June 13, 1982December 10, 2014After the Spielberg purchase, it was reported that retiree Arthur Bauer claimed to own another "Rosebud" sled.cite newsKesslerRobert E.Army retiree claims to have 'Rosebud'''[[The Capital Times]]'' (''[[Newsday]]'')June 22, 1982In early 1942 when Bauer was 12 he won an RKO publicity contest and selected the hardwood sled as his prize.cite webhttp://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/citizen-kane-1941-1111427-details.aspx?fromLot 59, Sale 7927[[Christie's]] Los Angeles auction catalogue, ''Film, Television & Pop''December 15, 199631In 1996, Bauer's estate offered the painted pine sled at auction throughChristie's.Bauer's son told CBS News that his mother had once wanted to paint the sled and use it as a plant stand, but Bauer told her to "just save it and put it in the closet."cite newsCBS News Transcripts''[[CBS]]''December 14, 1996The sled was sold to an anonymous bidder for $233,500.cite newsClark Gable's Oscar and 'Rosebud' sled sold''[[Associated Press]]''December 15, 1996

Welles's Oscar for Best Original Screenplay was believed to be lost until it was rediscovered in 1994. It was withdrawn from a 2007 auction atSotheby'swhen bidding failed to reach its estimate of $800,000 to $1.2 million.Owned by the charitableDax Foundation,it was auctioned for $861,542 in 2011 to an anonymous buyer.cite webhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2011/dec/21/orson-welles-citizen-kane-oscarBarnesHenryWelles's "Citizen Kane" Oscar sells for $860,000''[[The Guardian]]''LondonDecember 21, 2011December 10, 2014Mankiewicz's Oscar was sold at least twice, in 1999 and again in 2012, the latest price being $588,455.cite newshttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/29/oscars-auction-sold-citizen-kane_n_1309893.htmlOscars Auction: Statuettes from '30s, '40s Sold in Los Angeles''[[The Huffington Post]]'' (Associated Press)February 29, 2012December 10, 2014

In 1989, Mankiewicz's personal copy of theCitizen Kanescript was auctioned at Christie's. The leather-bound volume included the final shooting script and a carbon copy ofAmericanthat bore handwritten annotations purportedly made by Hearst's lawyers, who were said to have obtained it in the manner described by Kael in "#"Raising Kane"Raising Kane".cite newsReifRitaJune 16, 1989Auctionshttp://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/16/arts/auctions.htmlThe New York TimesJanuary 7, 2015cite newsMcDougallDennisJune 15, 1989Between the Lines That Raised 'Kane'http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-15/entertainment/ca-2642_1_charles-foster-kane-herman-j-mankiewicz-citizen-kaneLos Angeles TimesJanuary 7, 2015Estimated to bring $70,000 to $90,000,cite newsMay 7, 1989A New Look at 'Kane'http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1989/05/07/page/395/article/a-new-look-at-kane[[Chicago Tribune]]January 7, 2015it sold for a record $231,000.cite newsReifRitaJuly 2, 1989Antiqueshttp://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/02/books/antiques-books-tell-tales-of-art-and-money.htmlThe New York TimesJanuary 7, 2015

article.heading: Rights and home media
article.paragraph: The composited camera negative ofCitizen Kanewas destroyed in a New Jersey film laboratory fire in the 1970s. Subsequent prints were derived from a master positive (a fine-grain preservation element) made in the 1940s and originally intended for use in overseas distribution.cite bookMcGreeveyTomYeckJoanne L.Our Movie Heritage[[Rutgers University Press]]New Brunswick, NJ19970813524318135â36Modern techniques were used to produce a pristine print for a 50th Anniversary theatrical reissue in 1991 which Paramount released for then ownerTurner Broadcasting System,cite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/movies/for-citizen-kane-a-fresh-start-at-50.htmlRohterLarryLarry RohterFor 'Citizen Kane,' a Fresh Start at 50''The New York Times''February 20, 1991which earned $1.6 million in North America.cite webCitizen Kane (1941)[[Box Office Mojo]]http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?idDecember 8, 2014

In 1955, RKO sold the American television rights to its film library, includingCitizen Kane, toC&C GroupC&C Television Corp.cite bookBoddyWilliamFifties Television: The Industry and Its Critics[[University of Illinois Press]]Champaign, Illinois1993November 29, 2014https://books.google.com/books?id978-0-252-06299-5In 1960, television rights to the pre-1956 RKO library were acquired byUnited Artists. RKO kept the non-broadcast television rights to its library.cite newsMcCormickMoiraRKO Focuses On Upscale Market for Classic Films''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''https://books.google.com/books?idAugust 23, 198664

In 1976, when home video was in its infancy, entrepreneurSnuff Garrettbought cassette rights to the RKO library for whatUnited Press Internationaltermed "a pittance." In 1978 The Nostalgia Merchant released the film throughMedia Home Entertainment. By 1980 the 800-title library of The Nostalgia Merchant was earning $2.3 million a year. "Nobody wanted cassettes four years ago," Garrett told UPI. "It wasn't the first time people called me crazy. It was a hobby with me which became big business."cite newsScottVernonNostalgia King''United Press International''October 11, 1980RKO Home Video released the film onVHSandBetamaxin 1985.cite webhttp://www.worldcat.org/title/citizen-kane/oclc/016396308Citizen Kane (Film, 1985)[[WorldCat]]May 1, 2012

In 1984The Criterion Collectionreleased the film as itsList of Criterion Collection Laserdisc releasesfirstLaserDisc. It was made from a fine grain master positive provided by theUCLA Film and Television Archive.cite webhttp://www.criterion.com/current/posts/840-citizen-kaneSmithRoger P.From the Current â ''Citizen Kane''[[The Criterion Collection]]When told about the then new concept of having anaudio commentaryon the disc, Welles was skeptical but said "theoretically, thats good for teaching movies, so long as they dont talk nonsense."Rp283In 1992 Criterion released a new 50th Anniversary Edition LaserDisc. This version had an improved transfer and additional special features, including the documentaryThe Legacy of Citizen Kaneand Welles's early shortThe Hearts of Age.cite webhttp://www.dvduell.de/criterion_website/criterion/catalogpage-58.htmlCriterion: Citizen Kane: 50th Anniversary EditionThe Criterion Collection

Turner Broadcasting System acquired broadcast television rights to the RKO library in 1986cite webhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-03-26/business/8601220602_1_turner-broadcasting-system-ua-mgmTurner Acquires MGM/UA''Chicago Tribune''March 26, 1986and the full worldwide rights to the library in 1987.cite webhttp://articles.latimes.com/1987-12-10/business/fi-27906_1_rko-movieTurner Buys Rights to 800 RKO Movies''Los Angeles Times''December 10, 1987The RKO Home Video unit was reorganized into Turner Home Entertainment that year.cite webhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-03-29/entertainment/9201290077_1_old-time-hollywood-studios-turner-label-orson-welles''Chicago Tribune''An OK For RKOMarch 29, 1992In 1991 Turner released a 50th Anniversary Edition on VHS and as a collector's edition that includes the film, the documentaryReflections On Citizen Kane, Harlan Lebo's 50th anniversary album, a poster and a copy of the original script.cite newsWilkinsonJack E.VideoView -- UPI Arts & Entertainment; What's new on the home video scene...''United Press International''Washington D.C.August 29, 1991In 1996,Time Warneracquired Turner andWarner Home Videoabsorbed Turner Home Entertainment.cite webhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-11-14/news/9611150315_1_turner-broadcasting-system-turner-pictures-time-warnerTime Warner phasing out Turner Pictures: Time Warner Inc''Chicago Tribune''November 14, 1996Today, Time Warner'sWarner Bros.unit has distribution rights for the film.cite webhttp://www2.warnerbros.com/citizenkane/Citizen KaneWarner Brothers

In 2001 Warner Home Video released a 60th Anniversary Collectors EditionDVD. The two-disc DVD included feature-length commentaries by Ebert and Bogdanovich, as well as the documentaryThe Battle Over Citizen Kane. It was simultaneously released on VHS.cite webhttp://www.worldcat.org/title/citizen-kane/oclc/48011082Citizen Kane (VHS tape, 2001)WorldCatNovember 28, 2014The DVD was criticized for being "toobright,too clean; the dirt and grime had been cleared away, but so had a good deal of the texture, the depth, and the sense of film grain."cite webhttp://www.slate.com/articles/arts/dvdextras/2011/09/buy_the_citizen_kane_bluray.htmlKaplanFredBuy the Citizen Kane Blu-rayslate.comSeptember 13, 2011December 7, 2014

In 2003, Welles's daughter Beatrice Welles sued Turner Entertainment, claiming the Welles estate is the legalcopyrightholder of the film. She claimed that Welles's deal to terminate his contracts with RKO meant that Turner's copyright of the film was null and void. She also claimed that the estate of Orson Welles was owed 20% of the film's profits if her copyright claim was not upheld. In 2007 she was allowed to proceed with the lawsuit, overturning the 2004 decision in favor of Turner Entertainment on the issue of video rights.cite webhttp://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/31/business/fi-kane31Welles' daughter could get profit from 'Kane'''Los Angeles Times''August 8, 2011

In 2011 it was released onBlu-ray discand DVD in a 70th anniversary box set.cite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/18/movies/new-dvds-citizen-kane-going-places-birth-of-a-nation.html?scpTaylorCharlesThe New Season DVDs: Movies That Said, 'Look What I Can Do'''The New York Times''September 16, 2011TheSan Francisco Chroniclecalled it "the Blu-ray release of the year."cite webhttp://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?fJohnsonG. AllenDVD Review: ''Citizen Kane''''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''October 23, 2011Supplements included everything available on the 2001 Warner Home Video release, as well as the filmRKO 281and packaging extras that include a hardcover booklet and a folio containing a reproduction of the original souvenir program, miniature lobby cards and other memorabilia.cite webhttp://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/50668/citizen-kane/McQuainChristopherCitizen Kane (Blu-ray)[[DVD Talk]]September 7, 2011The Blu-ray DVD was scanned as4K resolutionfrom three different 35mm prints and rectified the quality issues of the 2001 DVD.
article.heading: Colorization controversy
article.paragraph: In the 1980s,Citizen Kanebecame a catalyst in the controversy over thefilm colorizationcolorizationofblack-and-whitefilms. One proponent of film colorization wasTed Turner,cite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/1986/11/04/movies/council-opposes-coloring-old-films.htmlMolotskyIrwinCouncil Opposes Coloring Old Films''The New York Times''November 4, 1986January 7, 2014whose Turner Entertainment Company owned the RKO library.cite newsTBS acquires rights to RKO film and television library''[[Business Wire]]''December 9, 1987A Turner Entertainment spokesperson initially stated thatCitizen Kanewould not be colorized,cite newsO'TooleLawrenceNo computer coloring for 'Kane'''[[The Globe and Mail]]''December 18, 1987but in July 1988 Turner said, "Citizen Kane?I'm thinking of colorizing it."cite newsBawdenJamesColorful Turner sees ''Citizen Kane'' in a different light''[[Toronto Star]]''July 28, 1988In early 1989 it was reported that two companies were producing color tests for Turner Entertainment. Criticism increased when filmmaker Henry Jaglom stated that shortly before his death Welles had implored him "don't let Ted Turner deface my movie with his crayons."cite webhttp://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/Turner-Says-It-s-Testing-To-Colorize-Citizen-Kane-/id-4c23402df90437fb0816882f7e22ff27Turner Says It's Testing To Colorize 'Citizen Kane'''Associated Press''January 30, 1989January 5, 2014

In February 1989 Turner Entertainment president Roger Mayer announced that work to colorize the film had been stopped due to provisions in Welles's 1939 contract with RKO that "could be read to prohibit colorization without permission of the Welles estate."cite webhttp://www.apnewsarchive.com/1989/We-ll-Never-Know-If-Rosebud-Was-Red/id-3da27b3969212eb7885db3dbd81b597eAntczykJohnWe'll Never Know If Rosebud Was Red''Associated Press''February 14, 1989January 5, 2014Mayer added that Welles's contract was "quite unusual" and "other contracts we have checked out are not like this at all."cite newsTurner won't colorize 'Kane'''[[United Press International]]''February 14, 1989Turner had only colorized the finalReel#Motion picture terminologyreelof the film before abandoning the project. In 1991 one minute of the colorized test footage was included in the BBCArena (TV series)ArenadocumentaryThe Complete Citizen Kane.efnThe colorized ''Citizen Kane'' footage appears at approximately 1:17:00.cite webhttp://www.wellesnet.com/the-complete-citizen-kane-is-now-online/The Complete Citizen Kaneâ documentary is now onlineWellesnetMay 13, 2013January 1, 2015

The colorization controversy was a factor in the passage of theNational Film Preservation Actin 1988 which created the National Film Registry the following year.ABC NewsanchorPeter Jenningsreported that "one major reason for doing this is to require people like the broadcaster Ted Turner, who's been adding color to some movies and re-editing others for television, to put notices on those versions saying that the movies have been altered".cite newsJenningsPeterPeter Jennings[[ABC World News|World News Tonight]]''[[ABC News]]'' Transcripts, ''[[American Broadcasting Company]]''September 19, 1989
